Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I could feel my phone buzzing in my apron pocket, the screen lighting up with message after message from Alex. Our argument from this morning had spiraled out of control, and now he was threatening to walk away if I didn’t call him back immediately. My heart pounded with panic—I knew I needed to talk to him, to fix things before it was too late. But the line at my register was long, and the end-of-shift rush meant I was handling hundreds of dollars in cash and credit. My manager had just reminded me how important it was to double-check every transaction, especially now, when one mistake could throw off the entire day’s balance. I tried to focus on the bills in my hand, but my mind kept drifting to Alex’s words, the fear of losing him gnawing at me. Each beep of the scanner felt heavier, my hands trembling as I counted change. I was torn—my boyfriend needed me to be present, to resolve our fight, but my job demanded my full attention. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I stood there, paralyzed, caught between the person I loved and the responsibility I couldn’t ignore.
